title: Vectors & Complex Numbers in Polar Form
description: Vector representation, operations, dot product, projections, and applications (work, forces, navigation). Complex numbers in trigonometric/polar form, multiplication and division, DeMoivre's Theorem, and nth roots of complex numbers.
goals: Represent vectors in component form; find magnitude and direction angle; compute unit vectors.
Perform vector addition, subtraction, and scalar multiplication algebraically and geometrically.
Compute the dot product; use it to find angles between vectors and test for orthogonality.
Compute scalar and vector projections; decompose a vector into parallel and perpendicular components.
Apply vectors to work, force resolution, equilibrium, and navigation/bearing problems.
Write complex numbers in polar form; multiply, divide, raise to powers (DeMoivre's), and find nth roots.
instructionalStrategy: Gradual release model; AI-led instruction using scaffold as scope
Emphasize geometric interpretation alongside algebraic computation
Spiral prior skills: trig functions, polar coordinates, Pythagorean theorem

scaffold.title: Vector Representation: Component Form, Magnitude, Direction
scaffold.content: A vector has both magnitude and direction. It can be represented as a directed line segment or in component form ⟨a, b⟩.
keyPoints: Component form: v = ⟨a, b⟩ = ⟨x₂-x₁, y₂-y₁⟩ from initial to terminal point.
Magnitude: ||v|| = √(a² + b²).
Direction angle θ: tan θ = b/a (adjust for quadrant).
Unit vector: v̂ = v/||v|| = ⟨a/||v||, b/||v||⟩.
Standard unit vectors: i = ⟨1, 0⟩, j = ⟨0, 1⟩. So v = ai + bj.
Zero vector ⟨0, 0⟩ has magnitude 0 and no defined direction.

examples.problem: Find the component form, magnitude, and direction angle of the vector from P(2, -1) to Q(-3, 4).
Find the unit vector in the direction of w = ⟨3, -4⟩.
Write the vector with magnitude 8 and direction angle 210° in component form.

scaffold.title: Vector Operations
scaffold.content: Vectors can be added, subtracted, and scaled. These operations follow the parallelogram rule geometrically and component-wise algebraically.
keyPoints: Addition: ⟨a₁, b₁⟩ + ⟨a₂, b₂⟩ = ⟨a₁+a₂, b₁+b₂⟩.
Subtraction: ⟨a₁, b₁⟩ - ⟨a₂, b₂⟩ = ⟨a₁-a₂, b₁-b₂⟩.
Scalar multiplication: k⟨a, b⟩ = ⟨ka, kb⟩. ||kv|| = |k| · ||v||.
Linear combination: c₁v₁ + c₂v₂.
Triangle inequality: ||u + v|| ≤ ||u|| + ||v||.
Geometric: tip-to-tail for addition; parallelogram rule for resultant.

examples.problem: Find a vector of magnitude 10 in the direction of v = ⟨3, 4⟩.
Express v = ⟨7, -3⟩ as a linear combination of u₁ = ⟨2, 1⟩ and u₂ = ⟨1, -1⟩.

scaffold.title: The Dot Product
scaffold.content: The dot product is a scalar operation on two vectors that encodes angle information. u · v = ||u|| ||v|| cos θ.
keyPoints: Algebraic: u · v = a₁a₂ + b₁b₂ (component-wise multiply and sum).
Geometric: u · v = ||u|| ||v|| cos θ where θ is the angle between them.
Angle formula: cos θ = (u · v)/(||u|| ||v||).
Orthogonal: u ⊥ v if and only if u · v = 0.
Properties: commutative, distributive, u · u = ||u||².
Sign: positive → acute angle, negative → obtuse angle, zero → right angle.

examples.problem: Find the angle between u = ⟨3, 1⟩ and v = ⟨-2, 4⟩.
Determine if u = ⟨6, -4⟩ and v = ⟨2, 3⟩ are orthogonal.
examples.solution: u·v = 6(2)+(-4)(3) = 12-12 = 0. Since u·v = 0, the vectors are orthogonal.

hints: If dot product is 0, vectors are orthogonal
problems.answer: a·b = 1(√3)+√3(-1) = √3-√3 = 0. The vectors are orthogonal: θ = 90°.

scaffold.title: Vector Applications: Work, Forces, Navigation
scaffold.content: Vectors model physical quantities with magnitude and direction: forces, velocities, displacements. The dot product computes work.
keyPoints: Work: W = F · d = ||F|| ||d|| cos θ where θ is angle between force and displacement.
Resultant force: sum of all force vectors. Equilibrium when resultant = zero vector.
Force resolution: decompose into horizontal and vertical components F = ⟨||F||cosθ, ||F||sinθ⟩.
Navigation: ground speed = airspeed vector + wind vector.
Bearing: measured clockwise from north. Convert: N θ° E → standard angle = 90° - θ.
Inclined plane: weight components parallel and perpendicular to slope.

examples.problem: A force of F = ⟨5, 8⟩ moves an object along displacement d = ⟨6, 2⟩. Find the work done.
A plane flies at 500 mph on heading N 30° W. Wind blows at 60 mph from due east. Find the ground speed and actual bearing.
A 200-lb crate sits on a ramp inclined at 25°. Find the force components parallel and perpendicular to the ramp.
examples.solution: Weight vector: 200 lb straight down. Parallel component (along ramp, pulling it down): F_∥ = 200 sin25° ≈ 200(0.4226) ≈ 84.5 lb. Perpendicular component (into ramp): F_⊥ = 200 cos25° ≈ 200(0.9063) ≈ 181.3 lb. Check: √(84.5²+181.3²) ≈ √(7140+32870) ≈ √40010 ≈ 200 ✓.

scaffold.title: Complex Numbers in Polar (Trigonometric) Form
scaffold.content: Complex numbers z = a + bi can be written in polar form z = r(cos θ + i sin θ) = r cis θ, connecting the complex plane to polar coordinates.
keyPoints: Modulus: r = |z| = √(a² + b²). Argument: θ = arctan(b/a) adjusted for quadrant.
Polar form: z = r(cos θ + i sin θ) = r cis θ.
Multiplication: z₁z₂ = r₁r₂ cis(θ₁ + θ₂). Multiply moduli, add arguments.
Division: z₁/z₂ = (r₁/r₂) cis(θ₁ - θ₂). Divide moduli, subtract arguments.
DeMoivre's Theorem: zⁿ = rⁿ cis(nθ). Raise modulus to nth power, multiply argument by n.
nth roots: ⁿ√z = ⁿ√r cis((θ + 2kπ)/n), k = 0, 1, ..., n-1. Always n distinct roots, equally spaced.

scaffold.title: Complex Numbers Polar Form — Worked Examples

examples.problem: Write z = -1 + √3 i in polar form and find z⁶ using DeMoivre's Theorem.
Find the product z₁z₂ where z₁ = 3 cis(π/4) and z₂ = 2 cis(5π/6).
Find all cube roots of z = 8i.
examples.solution: Write in polar: 8i = 8 cis(π/2). Cube roots: ³√8 cis((π/2 + 2kπ)/3) = 2 cis((π/2 + 2kπ)/3). k=0: 2 cis(π/6) = 2(√3/2 + i/2) = √3 + i. k=1: 2 cis(π/6 + 2π/3) = 2 cis(5π/6) = 2(-√3/2 + i/2) = -√3 + i. k=2: 2 cis(π/6 + 4π/3) = 2 cis(3π/2) = 2(0 - i) = -2i. The three cube roots are √3+i, -√3+i, and -2i.
